values.title: ViewController::Update is not called

content.raw:
I am attempting to modify (resurrect?) rendering/FPSViewController. I was advised by @nkoenig to change the position of the camera in FPSViewController::Update. However, it appears that ViewController:Update never gets called. You can test this by adding a print statement to either FPSViewController::Update or OrbitViewController::Update and adding the line

```
#!c++

gui::get_active_camera()->SetViewController(rendering::FPSViewController::GetTypeString());
```
to a plugin (the constructor of a GuiPlugin such as GUIExampleTimeWidget in examples works for me).

I do not see a print statement added to FPSViewController or OrbitController. Therefore, to continue my implementation I will have to modify rendering/Camera.cc.

ViewController::Update should be fixed so that it is called when it is intended to be called, or taken out so that it does not mislead developers.
content.html:
I am attempting to modify (resurrect?) rendering/FPSViewController. I was advised by @nkoenig to change the position of the camera in FPSViewController::Update. However, it appears that ViewController:Update never gets called. You can test this by adding a print statement to either FPSViewController::Update or OrbitViewController::Update and adding the line

gui::get_active_camera()->SetViewController(rendering::FPSViewController::GetTypeString());

to a plugin (the constructor of a GuiPlugin such as GUIExampleTimeWidget in examples works for me).

I do not see a print statement added to FPSViewController or OrbitController. Therefore, to continue my implementation I will have to modify rendering/Camera.cc.

ViewController::Update should be fixed so that it is called when it is intended to be called, or taken out so that it does not mislead developers.

values.title: Universal time

content.raw:
Is there a convenient way to share some notion of universal time across Gazebo? Gazebo seems to assume that T = 0 on simulation start. Is there a way to include a time offset, so that world plugins, sensors and models all have access to universal = offset + simulated?

I guess this would be useful in two ways:

1. Geomagnetism, ionospheric and satellite vehicle locations are indexed by global time, and it would be a nuisance to declare an offset in all plugins.

2. Global time can be pushed up to the ROS /clock so that rosbag saves the data as if it was recorded at simulated time, rather than wall time + simulated.

If I am overlooking something here, forgive me. However, the ```<spherical_coodinate>``` markup in SDF does this for coordinate frames / space. Why not have one for time?
content.html:
Is there a convenient way to share some notion of universal time across Gazebo? Gazebo seems to assume that T = 0 on simulation start. Is there a way to include a time offset, so that world plugins, sensors and models all have access to universal = offset + simulated?

I guess this would be useful in two ways:

  1. Geomagnetism, ionospheric and satellite vehicle locations are indexed by global time, and it would be a nuisance to declare an offset in all plugins.

  2. Global time can be pushed up to the ROS /clock so that rosbag saves the data as if it was recorded at simulated time, rather than wall time + simulated.

If I am overlooking something here, forgive me. However, the <spherical_coodinate> markup in SDF does this for coordinate frames / space. Why not have one for time?

values.title: KeyEventHandler::AddReleaseFilter does not detect lowercase letters

content.raw:
A line like this:

gui::KeyEventHandler::Instance()->AddReleaseFilter("Commands",
                        boost::bind(&GUIAratPlugin::OnKeyRelease,  this, _1));

will set up a callback that responds to key presses, but it does not distinguish between lower and uppercase letters.

gui::KeyEventHandler::Instance()->AddReleaseFilter("Commands", boost::bind(&GUIAratPlugin::OnKeyRelease, this, _1));

will set up a callback that responds to key presses, but it does not distinguish between lower and uppercase letters.

values.title: Collada up_axis tag

content.raw:
The Gazebo' collada loader doesn't parse the collada <up_axis> tag. More information follows:

The COLLADA <up_axis> is Y_UP by default (if nothing is specified) so if an asset is created in a modeler with different up_axis, you might want to apply some transform to all root nodes. 

This is what assimp does:
https://github.com/assimp/assimp/blob/master/code/ColladaLoader.cpp#L160
content.html:
The Gazebo' collada loader doesn't parse the collada <up_axis> tag. More information follows:

The COLLADA <up_axis> is Y_UP by default (if nothing is specified) so if an asset is created in a modeler with different up_axis, you might want to apply some transform to all root nodes.

This is what assimp does: https://github.com/assimp/assimp/blob/master/code/ColladaLoader.cpp#L160

values.title: file INSTALL fails with default CMAKE_INSTALL_PREFIX

content.raw:
If I configure gazebo 4.0 with cmake without a -DCMAKE_INSTALL_PREFIX  declaration it fails to install various configuration files with errors like the following:

file INSTALL cannot find "/opt/gazebo/gazebo-4.0.0/media/gui/looknfeel/OgreTray.looknfeel

The file listed in the error always exists in these errors. My process looks like this:

```
#!bash

cd gazebo-4.0
mkdir build
cd build
cmake -DCMAKE_INSTALL_PREFIX=/usr ..
make -j4
sudo checkinstall make install
```
The error occurs when checkinstall invokes make install.

The nested cmake list file that installs these files looks like the folowing:

set (files Falagard.xsd
           OgreTray.looknfeel
           TaharezLook.looknfeel
           Vanilla.looknfeel
           WindowsLook.looknfeel
           Gazebo.looknfeel
)


install(FILES ${files} DESTINATION ${CMAKE_INSTALL_PREFIX}/share/gazebo-${GAZEBO_VERSION}/media/gui/looknfeel/)


I couldn't figure out what the problem was or why explicitly declaring the install prefix might change things. If I'm doing something stupid in the compile process feel free to poke fun at me, but this is the process I've used succesfully for many other builds. Without an install prefix the default install directory has always been /usr/local, this is the first time I've seen the file INSTALL error.

values.title: Building Editor: Deleting all walls from a level mixes up levels added afterwards

content.raw:
1. Open Building Editor

2. Add some walls to the current level (`Level 1`)

3. Add a level (`Level 2`). It is created with walls cloned from the level below.

4. Delete all walls from `Level 2`

5. Add a level (`Level 3`). It is added overlapped with `Level 2` (if you go back and forth between them and add walls, you can see that the walls are added on the same height). This is confusing...

6. Delete `Level 1`. `Level 2` and `Level 3` go down together.

7. Delete `Level 2`. `Level 3` is moved below the ground - not good...
content.html:
1. Open Building Editor

  2. Add some walls to the current level (Level 1)

  3. Add a level (Level 2). It is created with walls cloned from the level below.

  4. Delete all walls from Level 2

  5. Add a level (Level 3). It is added overlapped with Level 2 (if you go back and forth between them and add walls, you can see that the walls are added on the same height). This is confusing...

  6. Delete Level 1. Level 2 and Level 3 go down together.

  7. Delete Level 2. Level 3 is moved below the ground - not good...

values.title: Cannot change SDF model name prior to insertion in world

content.html:
I'm trying to do the most elementary thing possible, and insert a model (from the model database) into a world programmatically, changing its name before insertion...

Following this tutorial I managed to insert a can of beer into the world without any issue:

worldPtr->InsertModelFile("model://beer");

I have no problem doing this when I specify SDF manually as a string:

sdf::SDF tmp;
tmp.SetFromString("___the_beer_sdf_ommited_for_clarity___");
sdf::ElementPtr model = tmp.root->GetElement("model");
model->GetAttribute("name")->SetFromString("my_beer");
worldPtr->InsertModelSDF(tmp);

It wasn't clear how to actually load a model into a sdf::SDF object. However, I poked around World.cc to work out how it is done internally. I tried to replicate the behaviour in my code, by implementing the following:

sdf::SDFPtr tmp;
tmp.reset(new sdf::SDF);
std::string filename = common::ModelDatabase::Instance()->GetModelFile("model://beer");
if (!sdf::readFile(filename, tmp))
    gzerr << "Unable to read sdf file.\n";
else
    worldPtr->InsertModelSDF(*tmp);

The issue is that the file is read, but the following error is printed to console:

[Err] [World.cc:1637] Unable to find a model, light, or actor in:
<sdf version='1.5'/>

This suggests to me that the SDF didn't read properly, as the <sdf> tag has no children. If I manually look at the model.sdf file for model://beer I can see that there are a number of child elements. Is this expected behaviour?

EDIT: I should add that I'm trying to do this in the Load method of a WorldPlugin and that the beer model is in a path in my GAZEBO_MODEL_PATH.

values.title: Sensor visualisations (wireless, sonar) cause client  tr1::bad_weak_ptr exception

content.raw:
My ultimate goal is to draw lines in Gazebo between a GPS sensor and models in the environment (satellite vehicles). Since there is no rendering visual for the GPS sensor, I thought I'd go ahead and copy/modify one of the existing sensor visuals.

However, I'm struggling to find a relatively simple visualisation that doesn't crash the Gazbo client. For example, trying to launch an example world...

```bash
gazebo /path/to/gazebo/source/worlds/wireless_sensors.world
```
... causes the following **client** exception to be thrown...

```bash
terminate called after throwing an instance of 'boost::exception_detail::clone_impl<boost::exception_detail::error_info_injector<boost::bad_weak_ptr> >'
  what():  tr1::bad_weak_ptr
```

This happens with Ubuntu 14.04 ```gazebo4``` and the current default source. I have narrowed it down to turning on sensor visuals (sonar, wireless transceiver).

Can anybody replicate this issue?

values.title: Doxygen documentation for Pose gazebo::math::Pose::operator+ is unhelpful

content.raw:
The documentation is as follows:

Pose gazebo::math::Pose::operator+	(	const Pose & 	_pose	)	const

Addition operator A is the transform from O to P specified in frame O B is the transform from P to Q specified in frame P then, B + A is the transform from O to Q specified in frame O.

Parameters:
[in]	_pose	Pose to add to this pose
Returns:
The resulting pose

I have no idea what A, O, P, B, or Q are. I mean, I can guess, but it's not immediately clear how they relate to the input and output parameters.

values.title: Bounding box disappears when manipulating model (rotate/translate/scale)

content.raw:
1. Insert a model

2. Select the model (bounding box is attached to model)

3. Select translate mode (manipulator is attached to model, bb still there)

4. Drag a manipulator handle and release -> the bounding box disappears but the manipulator is still attached.

I find this a bit confusing, specially when there are many models. I think that the bounding box should be showing for as long as the model is selected.

values.title: Highlight joint when selected using ModelListWidget

content.raw:
I was just testing out the improved joint visualization in pull request #1258. I tested with several models involving multiple joints (polaris_ranger_ev, cart_*), and it can be difficult to identify which joint visual is which.

values.title: Proper joint torque feedback

content.raw:
I have several questions regarding how to properly implement joint torque feedback in Gazebo. I don't know if the bug tracker is the right place to post this questions, but given that I will get in the internal details of Gazebo and this question could lead to some new physics-related test, I prefer to post here instead of posting in Gazebo Answers. To keep the discussion simple I will refer only to revolute joints, but the concepts can be generalized to other types of joints. I also disregard joint stiffness, mainly because I don't have a clear idea in my mind on how it is implemented in Gazebo. Sorry if I probably write obvious notions for stating my point, but I prefer to clearly define concepts as much as possible to avoid misunderstandings. 

At this moment, Gazebo is not simulating any kind of motor dynamics, but it is simulating joint friction (currently only viscous friction model, with an additional Coulomb/dry friction tem is being implemented in [issue 381](#!/osrf/gazebo/issue/381/ode-joints-dont-support-friction-parameter) ). 

Disregarding torque limits, we can then define the torques applied by any controller as: 

 * the *motor torque* (i.e. the the quantity setted by the `JointController` with the `Joint::SetForce()` method). 

This *motor torque* is then equal to the difference (or addiction, depending on how you define the different components) between:

 * the *joint torque* (i.e. the torque that, for a 1-DOF fixed base robot with no gravity and no external force, we find on the left side of the dynamics equation `I \ddot{q} = \tau`) and

 * the *friction torque* (i.e. the torque opposing the motion due to friction).


Currently the joint torque feedback is implemented in `gazebo_ros_control` (and also in our `gazebo-yarp-plugins`) using the `Joint::GetForce()` method. This method, as far as I was able to test (the documentation says that it is not implemented, so I guess it is simply not updated), just returns the last value set through `Joint::SetForce()`. Using the notation used in this issue, this function returns the *motor torques*.  However, for proper force control, we are interested in *joint torque*. 

To see why we want to control the *joint torques* let's take as an example a joint controlled with a classical impedance control scheme: `\tau = K(q_m-q_d)`, where:

 
 * `\tau` is the controlled torque (Nm)
 * `K` is the impedance stiffness (Nm/[rad])
 * `q_m` is the measured position of the joint ([rad])
 * `q_d` is the desired position of the joint ([rad])

Let's imagine that a Coulomb friction of 1Nm is acting on the joint, and the impedance stiffness is set to 1 Nm/[rad]. If the controlled torque is the *motor torque*, we will have a *deadband* of 1 [rad] around the desired position, where no actual *joint torque* is exerted on the robot. This because in the deadband all the commanded torque are lower then 1 Nm, and so they are counterbalanced by the Coulomb *friction torque*. 

What usually happens in real robots is that an inner loop for controlling *joint torque* by commanding appropriate *motor torques*, using some kind of *joint torque* feedback (SEA springs, strain gauges, ...). At the best of my knowledge, there is no clean way to get *joint torques* in Gazebo. A possible solution that should work is to use the output of `Joint::GetForceTorque()` and to project it on the joint axis, but I still have to test it.

 Even if this works, do you think it could make sense to have a proper method for the `physics::Joint` class for returning *joint torques*?

I have several questions regarding how to properly implement joint torque feedback in Gazebo. I don't know if the bug tracker is the right place to post this questions, but given that I will get in the internal details of Gazebo and this question could lead to some new physics-related test, I prefer to post here instead of posting in Gazebo Answers. To keep the discussion simple I will refer only to revolute joints, but the concepts can be generalized to other types of joints. I also disregard joint stiffness, mainly because I don't have a clear idea in my mind on how it is implemented in Gazebo. Sorry if I probably write obvious notions for stating my point, but I prefer to clearly define concepts as much as possible to avoid misunderstandings.

At this moment, Gazebo is not simulating any kind of motor dynamics, but it is simulating joint friction (currently only viscous friction model, with an additional Coulomb/dry friction tem is being implemented in issue 381 ).

Disregarding torque limits, we can then define the torques applied by any controller as:

  • the motor torque (i.e. the the quantity setted by the JointController with the Joint::SetForce() method).

This motor torque is then equal to the difference (or addiction, depending on how you define the different components) between:

  • the joint torque (i.e. the torque that, for a 1-DOF fixed base robot with no gravity and no external force, we find on the left side of the dynamics equation I \ddot{q} = \tau) and

  • the friction torque (i.e. the torque opposing the motion due to friction).

Currently the joint torque feedback is implemented in gazebo_ros_control (and also in our gazebo-yarp-plugins) using the Joint::GetForce() method. This method, as far as I was able to test (the documentation says that it is not implemented, so I guess it is simply not updated), just returns the last value set through Joint::SetForce(). Using the notation used in this issue, this function returns the motor torques. However, for proper force control, we are interested in joint torque.

To see why we want to control the joint torques let's take as an example a joint controlled with a classical impedance control scheme: \tau = K(q_m-q_d), where:

  • \tau is the controlled torque (Nm)
  • K is the impedance stiffness (Nm/[rad])
  • q_m is the measured position of the joint ([rad])
  • q_d is the desired position of the joint ([rad])

Let's imagine that a Coulomb friction of 1Nm is acting on the joint, and the impedance stiffness is set to 1 Nm/[rad]. If the controlled torque is the motor torque, we will have a deadband of 1 [rad] around the desired position, where no actual joint torque is exerted on the robot. This because in the deadband all the commanded torque are lower then 1 Nm, and so they are counterbalanced by the Coulomb friction torque.

What usually happens in real robots is that an inner loop for controlling joint torque by commanding appropriate motor torques, using some kind of joint torque feedback (SEA springs, strain gauges, ...). At the best of my knowledge, there is no clean way to get joint torques in Gazebo. A possible solution that should work is to use the output of Joint::GetForceTorque() and to project it on the joint axis, but I still have to test it.

Even if this works, do you think it could make sense to have a proper method for the physics::Joint class for returning joint torques?

values.title: Box::GetCenter() returns wrong value

content.html:
Hi,

i noticed a bug in the BB code, namely at the Box::GetCenter()

math::Vector3 Box::GetCenter() const
{
  Vector3 size = this->GetSize();
  size /= 2.0;
  return this->min + size;
}

because GetSize(); returns only positive values this will give false values for BB in the negative areas.

a correct version would be:

math::Vector3 Box::GetCenter() const
{
  return  this->min + (this->max - this->min) / 2;
}

Cheers, Andrei

UPDATE:

Created a pull request and also changed the Box_TEST to have an example with negative valued BB

values.title: maxWaitCount in gazebo.cc prevents worlds from loading

content.html:
In gazebo.cc, setupClient waits for a hard-coded maximum of 10 seconds before giving up on receiving namespaces (lines 178-194):

  common::Time waitTime(1, 0);
  int waitCount = 0;
  int maxWaitCount = 10;

  // Wait for namespaces.
  while (!gazebo::transport::waitForNamespaces(waitTime) &&
      (waitCount++) < maxWaitCount)
  {
    gzwarn << "Waited " << waitTime.Double() << "seconds for namespaces.\n";
  }

  if (waitCount >= maxWaitCount)
  {
    gzerr << "Waited " << (waitTime * waitCount).Double()
      << " seconds for namespaces. Giving up.\n";
  }

This is problematic for some users trying to load and render large worlds (e.g. drc_practice_task_2.world in drcsim). If gzserver spends more than 10 seconds loading model data, then gzclient will time out and the user is left hanging. One hack around this is to launch gzserver, then launch gzclient after some time has passed (12 seconds in the case of DRC task 2). Another is to simply increase the maxWaitTime.

However, a better long-term solution may be to add more communication between client and server at this stage in gazebo intialization. The server should be able to send a message to the client to keep waiting for topic namespaces.

values.title: bullet and simbody fail at moving/spawning model

content.raw:
The `gazebo/test/integration/sim_events.cc` tests is not robust when running with all physics engines. The following tests were disabled (except for ode):

* ModelInAndOutOfRegion: a model is moved using SetWorldPose

* SpawnAndDeleteModel: a model is added to the simulator

These tests will often work, and sometime crash. You can set the bool variable `SKIP_FAILING_TESTS` to false to run them.
content.html:
The gazebo/test/integration/sim_events.cc tests is not robust when running with all physics engines. The following tests were disabled (except for ode):

  • ModelInAndOutOfRegion: a model is moved using SetWorldPose

  • SpawnAndDeleteModel: a model is added to the simulator

These tests will often work, and sometime crash. You can set the bool variable SKIP_FAILING_TESTS to false to run them.

values.title: System fails to run all of a sudden (on file that ran fine moments before) from seemingly outside (packages) cause.

content.raw:
Was testing in Gazebo fine when started receiving exceptions that my model file did not parse properly.  The model file was unchanged from instance to instance and the underlying support code I utilized to validate was unchanged.  After double and triple checking that these files were stable (including redownloading a guaranteed working copy from my repo), I decided to reboot.  Upon beginning to reboot, I noted that dart had attempted to push an update today (4.2), but failed due to my having 4.1 and the system would not integrate dart-core4.2 with 4.1 on the machine.  After reboot, I continued having the same problem with my models not parsing.  Decided to try to reinstall gazebo, but it now failed to cmake because system did not have dart 4.2 (note, I did not pull gazebo this all changed in the background).  Wiped dart (which wiped libccd) and pulled 4.2 which pulled libccd2.  Now on make, ld fails because I no longer have libccd.  

Do you @nkoenig or @hsu have any advice to get me running again?  I am gimped at the moment.  My next step is to wipe gazebo, pull and start over.  Not sure why the dart push (or other general push) killed my system, but it somehow did.

values.title: answers.gazebosim.org default settings are spammy

content.raw:
The default email settings for new accounts on answers.gazebosim.org result in an email for every new question and answer. This is pretty spammy for users that just create an account to ask one question or browse the forums.

As a side note, my email provider (AOL) is marking all email from the answers.gazebosim.org domain as spam because the SPF rules for gzebosim.org are not set up. This is almost certainly causing other email vendors to mark your emails as spam as well.

INTEGRATION_plugin test failures in gazebo3 - default

content.raw:
The `INTEGRATION_plugin` test was added to gazebo_1.9 and recently merged forward to the other release branches (pull request #1289). The test status is as follows:

* [passing in gazebo_1.9](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/gazebo/job/gazebo-any-devel-precise-amd64-gpu-ati/95/testReport/%28root%29/PluginTest/)
* [passing in gazebo_2.2](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/gazebo/job/gazebo-any-devel-precise-amd64-gpu-ati/96/testReport/%28root%29/PluginTest/)
* failing in gazebo_3.1 (verified on my machine)
* gazebo_4.1 untested (I assume it's also failing)
* [failing in default](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/gazebo/job/gazebo-default-devel-trusty-amd64-gpu-nvidia/147/testReport/junit/%28root%29/INTEGRATION_plugin/test_ran/)

On my machine with the `gazebo_3.1` branch, the test fails when trying to find a specific error message in the `~/.gazebo/test.log` file:
~~~
[==========] Running 3 tests from 1 test case.
[----------] Global test environment set-up.
[----------] 3 tests from PluginTest
[ RUN      ] PluginTest.ModelExceptionConstructor
[Msg] Waiting for master.
[Msg] Connected to gazebo master @ http://127.0.0.1:11345
[Msg] Publicized address: 172.23.2.90
[Err] [Model.cc:749] Exception occured in the constructor of plugin with name[exception] and filename[libExceptionModelPluginConstructor.so]. This plugin will not run.
[Dbg] [ServerFixture.cc:144] ServerFixture load in 0.9 seconds, timeout after 600 seconds
test/integration/plugin.cc:58: Failure
Value of: loggedString.find( "Exception occured in the constructor of plugin with name") != std::string::npos
  Actual: false
Expected: true
[Dbg] [plugin.cc:59] Gazebo multi-robot simulator, version 3.2.0Copyright (C) 2012-2014 Open Source Robotics Foundation.Released under the Apache 2 License.http://gazebosim.org
[Dbg] [ServerFixture.cc:95] ServerFixture::Unload
[  FAILED  ] PluginTest.ModelExceptionConstructor (1140 ms)
[ RUN      ] PluginTest.ModelExceptionInit
[Msg] Waiting for master.
[Msg] Connected to gazebo master @ http://127.0.0.1:11345
[Msg] Publicized address: 172.23.2.90
[Err] [Model.cc:798] Exception occured in the Init function of plugin with name[exception] and filename[libExceptionModelPluginInit.so]. This plugin will not run
[Dbg] [ServerFixture.cc:144] ServerFixture load in 0.7 seconds, timeout after 600 seconds
test/integration/plugin.cc:94: Failure
Value of: loggedString.find( "Exception occured in the Init function of plugin with name") != std::string::npos
  Actual: false
Expected: true
[Dbg] [ServerFixture.cc:95] ServerFixture::Unload
[  FAILED  ] PluginTest.ModelExceptionInit (937 ms)
[ RUN      ] PluginTest.ModelExceptionLoad
[Msg] Waiting for master.
[Msg] Connected to gazebo master @ http://127.0.0.1:11345
[Msg] Publicized address: 172.23.2.90
[Err] [Model.cc:780] Exception occured in the Load function of plugin with name[exception] and filename[libExceptionModelPluginLoad.so]. This plugin will not run.
[Dbg] [ServerFixture.cc:144] ServerFixture load in 0.9 seconds, timeout after 600 seconds
test/integration/plugin.cc:129: Failure
Value of: loggedString.find( "Exception occured in the Load function of plugin with name") != std::string::npos
  Actual: false
Expected: true
[Dbg] [ServerFixture.cc:95] ServerFixture::Unload
[  FAILED  ] PluginTest.ModelExceptionLoad (1139 ms)
[----------] 3 tests from PluginTest (3216 ms total)

[----------] Global test environment tear-down
[==========] 3 tests from 1 test case ran. (3216 ms total)
[  PASSED  ] 0 tests.
[  FAILED  ] 3 tests, listed below:
[  FAILED  ] PluginTest.ModelExceptionConstructor
[  FAILED  ] PluginTest.ModelExceptionInit
[  FAILED  ] PluginTest.ModelExceptionLoad

 3 FAILED TESTS
~~~

There are two problems:

1. The location of the test log files changed with gazebo_3.1, and has also changed on the default branch. So the test should be updated with the proper location, or perhaps an accessor for the name of the current log file.

2. The `gzerr` statements are being logged to the file for unit tests derived from `AutoLogFixture`, but there are problems with the integration tests derived from `ServerFixture`. All I see in the log files from these tests is the preamble:
~~~
Gazebo multi-robot simulator, version 4.1.0
Copyright (C) 2012-2014 Open Source Robotics Foundation.
Released under the Apache 2 License.
http://gazebosim.org


~~~
Perhaps the FileLogger buffer needs to be flushed at the end of the test?

values.title: Building Editor: crash if Visual SceneNode is NULL

content.raw:
This is a bit tricky to reproduce, but if you create a building in the Building Editor, save it and exit and delete the resulting model by pressing the Delete key on the keyboard, the model name in the Scene Tree will remain. If you click on the name and delete that, then open the Building Editor again and try to draw something, Gazebo will crash with:

```
[Err] [Visual.cc:140] Unable to get parent scene node
***** Internal Program Error - assertion (this->dataPtr->sceneNode) failed in void gazebo::rendering::Visual::SetPosition(const gazebo::math::Vector3&):
/home/jackie/gazebo/gazebo/rendering/Visual.cc(1540): Visual SceneNode is NULL```
content.html:

values.title: Building Editor: Individual walls manipulable, bounding box select buggy for building with default name

content.raw:
After saving a building with the default name and exiting the Building Editor, you can select individual walls and stairs and manipulate the individual components in translate/rotate/scale mode.

If you select the buggy building in the World tab, the building will not be highlighted with a bounding box. Similarly, if you select the building in the main window, the bounding box will render but the name will not be highlighted in the World tab. Also, turning the bounding box is buggy.

Appears to be related to issue #1351 (the crash described in #1351 is reproducible if you delete the buggy building described above then re-open the Building Editor and try to draw walls).
content.html:
After saving a building with the default name and exiting the Building Editor, you can select individual walls and stairs and manipulate the individual components in translate/rotate/scale mode.

If you select the buggy building in the World tab, the building will not be highlighted with a bounding box. Similarly, if you select the building in the main window, the bounding box will render but the name will not be highlighted in the World tab. Also, turning the bounding box is buggy.

Appears to be related to issue #1351 (the crash described in #1351 is reproducible if you delete the buggy building described above then re-open the Building Editor and try to draw walls).

values.title: ABI problem for gazebo4

content.raw:
In pull request #1284 (merged to gazebo_2.2), two new private member variables were [added to ODELink](#!/osrf/gazebo/pull-request/1284/issue-243-fix-link-getworldlinearaccel-and/diff#chg-gazebo/physics/ode/ODELink.hh). This [doesn't affect ABI for gazebo_2.2](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/API_ABI%20checker/job/gazebo-any_to_any-abichecker-precise-amd64/129/API_ABI_report/) because the ode headers weren't installed in 2.2.

The ode headers are now installed as of pull request #1183, which has just been released in gazebo 4.1.0, which was just before pull request #1284 was merged.

So, when we merge gazebo_2.2 forward, it will [break ABI for gazebo4](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-any_to_any-abichecker-precise-amd64/130/API_ABI_report/).
content.html:
In pull request #1284 (merged to gazebo_2.2), two new private member variables were added to ODELink. This doesn't affect ABI for gazebo_2.2 because the ode headers weren't installed in 2.2.

The ode headers are now installed as of pull request #1183, which has just been released in gazebo 4.1.0, which was just before pull request #1284 was merged.

So, when we merge gazebo_2.2 forward, it will break ABI for gazebo4.

values.title: GPU ray sensor/GPU laser

content.raw:
Are there some plans of making the GPU ray sensor/GPU laser work properly?

I'm currently using Gazebo 2.2.5 on Ubuntu 14.04, compatible with ROS Indigo.
The basic idea is to simulate a Velodyne lidar. As you can forget the CPU ray sensor for that purpose (too slow), the GPU rendering would be great to use. The problem is that in the current version the code is buggy, it only works for a single 360-degrees-ray, but not for 32 vertical lasers.

The problem has already been pointed out (#!/osrf/gazebo/issue/946/gpu-ray-sensor-vertical-ranges) with a tentative solution that provides better results, yet not perfect. Furthermore, it's far too slow (1-2 turns per second, instead of 10 turns per second for a Velodyne 32).

I haven't looked deeply into the code, but this should not be too complicated to have a working solution. And this would be really useful. We have an implementation in our custom-made simulator (https://github.com/kralf/morsel), but we have decided to switch to Gazebo recently.
content.html:
Are there some plans of making the GPU ray sensor/GPU laser work properly?

I'm currently using Gazebo 2.2.5 on Ubuntu 14.04, compatible with ROS Indigo. The basic idea is to simulate a Velodyne lidar. As you can forget the CPU ray sensor for that purpose (too slow), the GPU rendering would be great to use. The problem is that in the current version the code is buggy, it only works for a single 360-degrees-ray, but not for 32 vertical lasers.

The problem has already been pointed out (#!/osrf/gazebo/issue/946/gpu-ray-sensor-vertical-ranges) with a tentative solution that provides better results, yet not perfect. Furthermore, it's far too slow (1-2 turns per second, instead of 10 turns per second for a Velodyne 32).

I haven't looked deeply into the code, but this should not be too complicated to have a working solution. And this would be really useful. We have an implementation in our custom-made simulator (https://github.com/kralf/morsel), but we have decided to switch to Gazebo recently.

values.title: Grab / Drag / Grip handles should change the cursor on mouseover

content.raw:
In the Gazebo UI when you mouse over a the three lines of a grab / drag handle the cursor does not change. 

This hurts the discoverability of the feature and makes it more difficult to understand the bounding box where grabbing will have an effect. 

The standard is to alter the cursor to a closed hand, partial open hand, or other alternate cursor to indicate the affordance.
content.html:
In the Gazebo UI when you mouse over a the three lines of a grab / drag handle the cursor does not change.

This hurts the discoverability of the feature and makes it more difficult to understand the bounding box where grabbing will have an effect.

The standard is to alter the cursor to a closed hand, partial open hand, or other alternate cursor to indicate the affordance.

values.title: Dragging open the Joints tab should have a visual clue prior to being "full open"

content.raw:
To open the joints tab you have to:

1. Understand the grab handle affordance
2. Locate and hold over the affordance bounding box and
3. Drag left >120px (half the window width)

(1 and 2 are addressed in a separate ticket.)

A desired behavior option would be that the pane begins to slide open after moving any number of pixels, but on mouse up "snaps" to the full open 240 wide position.

Even if the pane were blank / unpopulated during the slide, this would be a step in improving the usability / discoverability of this feature.

values.title: After apt-get update 12/28/2014 gazebo has ogre exceptions and rendering assertions.

content.raw:
After running an apt-get update on my computer on 12/28 gazebo stopped working on DRCSim related worlds + it has strange behavior as it does not run when I even type `gazebo` on the command line. 

Here is my computer configuration:

Running Ubuntu 12.04 Precise
ROS Hydro

I have tried resoliving this problems by using pre-complied binaries and also running programs built from source.

For pre-compiled binaries, this is what I have:
```
ii  gazebo4                              4.1.0-1~precise                      Open Source Robotics Simulator
ii  gazebo4-common                       4.1.0-1~precise                      Open Source Robotics Simulator - Shared files
ii  gazebo4-plugin-base                  4.1.0-1~precise                      Open Source Robotics Simulator - base plug-ins
```

When installed from Source, i installed the following:
drcsim  gazebo_ros_pkgs  osrf-common  sandia-hand.

I have tried updating to the latest packages:
(hg pull) and (git pull) and then run catkin_make install.

Before the updated, I ran nvidia through bumblebee and gazebo worked fine before my last update. This is my current configuration:

sudo dpkg --get-selections | grep nvidia 

```
bumblebee-nvidia				install
nvidia-304					install
nvidia-common				install
nvidia-current					install
nvidia-settings					install
```

Some strange behavior.

None of the following work: 

```
>> gazebo
>> gzserver
>> gzclient (opens a black window but if anything is loaded on it, it fails)
```

However, the following command does work:
`roslaunch gazebo_ros mud_world.launch`

And, no drcsim worlds work:

```
roslaunch drcsim_gazebo atlas.launch fails.
```

Two sources of feedback:

First, terminal indicates a gzserver assertion error for gazebo rendering a scene:
```
gzserver: /usr/include/boost/smart_ptr/shared_ptr.hpp:418: T* boost::shared_ptr<T>::operator->() const [with T = gazebo::rendering::Scene]: Assertion `px != 0' failed.
```

If I try to use a version of drcsim that uses the cpu (graphics enabled) version of drcsim, I get an OGRE exception about rendering color:

```
terminate called after throwing an instance of 'Ogre::ItemIdentityException'
  what():  OGRE EXCEPTION(5:ItemIdentityException): Could not find material Gazebo/Green in SimpleRenderable::setMaterial at /build/buildd/ogre-1.7.4/OgreMain/src/OgreSimpleRenderable.cpp (line 63)
```
If I look at the log files generated by ROS, I find the following type of errors:

```
rosout.log:0.537000000 ERROR [/tmp/buildd/drcsim-4.1.1/drcsim_gazebo_ros_plugins/src/VRCPlugin.cpp:1537(VRCPlugin::Robot::InsertModel) [topics: /rosout, /clock, /gazebo/link_states, /gazebo/model_states, /gazebo/parameter_descriptions, /gazebo/parameter_updates] failed to spawn model from rosparam: [robot_description]...

rosout.log:0.538000000 ERROR [/tmp/buildd/drcsim-4.1.1/drcsim_gazebo_ros_plugins/src/VRCPlugin.cpp:1524(VRCPlugin::Robot::InsertModel) [topics: /rosout, /clock, /gazebo/link_states, /gazebo/model_states, /gazebo/parameter_descriptions, /gazebo/parameter_updates] robot initial spawn pose not found...

rosout.log:0.538000000 ERROR [/tmp/buildd/drcsim-4.1.1/drcsim_gazebo_ros_plugins/src/VRCPlugin.cpp:1537(VRCPlugin::Robot::InsertModel) [topics: /rosout, /clock, /gazebo/link_states, /gazebo/model_states, /gazebo/parameter_descriptions, /gazebo/parameter_updates] failed to spawn model from rosparam: [robot_description].
```

values.title: InelasticCollision/0 ODE test failure

content.raw:
The behavior of ODELink::GetWorldForce was changed in pull request #1284, targeted to gazebo_2.2.  I discovered a [test failure](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-default-devel-trusty-amd64-gpu-nvidia/169/testReport/junit/%28root%29/PhysicsEngines_PhysicsTest/InelasticCollision_0/) in gazebo3 and up after merging forward:
~~~
195: [ RUN      ] PhysicsEngines/PhysicsTest.InelasticCollision/0
...
195: test/integration/physics.cc:962: Failure
195: Value of: box_model->GetLink("link")->GetWorldForce() == math::Vector3(f, 0, 0)
195:   Actual: false
195: Expected: true
~~~

Prior to pull request #1284, the `Link::GetWorldForce` function returned a measure of the current force on a link. After, it returned a cached value from the previous timestep. [This test](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/default/test/integration/physics.cc#cl-960) is now failing because it calls `Link::SetForce` and then immediately expects `Link::GetWorldForce` to match that value. I believe it would require a simulation step for the force to propagate to the cache.

@hsu what is the intended behavior of `Link::GetWorldForce`? Is the test expectation valid? Will this cause problems for users such that we shouldn't push this out on a patch release?

Also, this should be a reminder that adding features to old branches can cause problems when merging forward.
content.html:
The behavior of ODELink::GetWorldForce was changed in pull request #1284, targeted to gazebo_2.2. I discovered a test failure in gazebo3 and up after merging forward:

195: [ RUN      ] PhysicsEngines/PhysicsTest.InelasticCollision/0
...
195: test/integration/physics.cc:962: Failure
195: Value of: box_model->GetLink("link")->GetWorldForce() == math::Vector3(f, 0, 0)
195:   Actual: false
195: Expected: true

Prior to pull request #1284, the Link::GetWorldForce function returned a measure of the current force on a link. After, it returned a cached value from the previous timestep. This test is now failing because it calls Link::SetForce and then immediately expects Link::GetWorldForce to match that value. I believe it would require a simulation step for the force to propagate to the cache.

@hsu what is the intended behavior of Link::GetWorldForce? Is the test expectation valid? Will this cause problems for users such that we shouldn't push this out on a patch release?

Also, this should be a reminder that adding features to old branches can cause problems when merging forward.

values.title: SDF Param Error: Unable to set value for radius

content.raw:
When trying to insert a sphere or cylinder into the Model Editor, I get the following error and the sphere/cylinder comes up with a radius of 1 m instead of 0.5 m.

~~~
Error [Param.cc:181] Unable to set value [0,5] for key[radius]
~~~

The same error comes up when inserting these shapes on the main window, but the shape appears in the correct size.

This seems to have been introduced in the latest commits, I wasn't getting this error on Friday.

I've updated SDF to the latest default branch and the error persists.

The error seems to come from this call, but I'm not sure exactly where the problem lies.

~~~
sdf::ElementPtr cylinderElem = geomElem->AddElement("cylinder");
(cylinderElem->GetElement("radius"))->Set(_radius);
~~~

values.title: Building Editor: It's not possible to select draw modes

content.raw:
1. Open Building Editor

2. On the palette, click on any brush

3. The brush becomes selected but nothing else works. It's not possible to draw on the 2D View.

This happens because the draw mode is cancelled immediately after, from `EditorView::OnColorSelected`.

Not sure why, but this is only happening after the latest commits.

I have a solution [here](#!/osrf/gazebo/commits/034ca8fe1995f72ca339bcf3e2498eb8e9a276f8)

  2. On the palette, click on any brush

This happens because the draw mode is cancelled immediately after, from EditorView::OnColorSelected.

content.raw:
The mac homebrew [builds are failing](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-any-devel-homebrew-amd64/337/) since boost 1.57 has been released as the homebrew default. It looks like another instance of [QTBUG-22829](https://bugreports.qt-project.org/browse/QTBUG-22829) (see pull request #615 for a previous fix).

~~~
Users/jenkins/jenkins.pnmx/Cellar/boost/1.57.0/include/boost/type_traits/detail/has_binary_operator.hp:50: Parse error at "BOOST_JOIN"
make[2]: *** [gazebo/gui/viewers/moc_ImageView.cxx] Error 1
make[1]: *** [gazebo/gui/viewers/CMakeFiles/gazebo_gui_viewers.dir/all] Error 2
make[1]: *** Waiting for unfinished jobs....
~~~

We will need to wrap some more header file includes in `#ifndef Q_MOC_RUN`

values.title: Proposal for naming release branches

content.raw:
We have been naming release branches like `gazebo_X.Y` (`gazebo_1.9`, `gazebo_2.2`, `gazebo_3.1`, etc.). When we release a new minor version, we create a new branch and basically the previous minors (ie. after `gazebo_3.1` no patch releases to `gazebo_3.0`).

If we are only going to maintain one branch for each major version, I would propose naming our branches without the minor number (ie. `gazeboX`). It would simplify our branching. We could still go back and create a minor branch if needed, but we could default to keeping it simple.

So, when we are ready to branch for gazebo 5.0, can we call the branch `gazebo5`?
content.html:
We have been naming release branches like gazebo_X.Y (gazebo_1.9, gazebo_2.2, gazebo_3.1, etc.). When we release a new minor version, we create a new branch and basically the previous minors (ie. after gazebo_3.1 no patch releases to gazebo_3.0).

If we are only going to maintain one branch for each major version, I would propose naming our branches without the minor number (ie. gazeboX). It would simplify our branching. We could still go back and create a minor branch if needed, but we could default to keeping it simple.

So, when we are ready to branch for gazebo 5.0, can we call the branch gazebo5?
